passages.text: Monthly check on the LatAm consumer: We present an updated analysis and chartbook of key consumer- related macro and industry data that we monitor in LatAm. These help us interpret current trends and anticipate the operating environment for consumer companies under our coverage.

Brazil was relatively positive. The labor market remains strong, with L3M average real wage growth broadly stable at \(+3.0\%\) yoy in June (vs. \(+3.1\%\) yoy in May) and unemployment down 40bp mom to \(5.8\%\) , reaching record lows. Headline inflation decelerated slightly to \(5.2\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(5.4\%\) yoy in Jun), despite the pressure in food inflation, which accelerated to \(7.4\%\) yoy in the same period (vs. \(6.7\%\) yoy in Jun). Net purchasing power improved in June, as the gap between nominal wages and F&B inflation widened to \(+220\) bps (vs. \(+120\) bp in May). Early Aug data points to even higher food inflation, which merits watching for read- across to purchasing power. Consumer confidence continued to decline (- 7.6% yoy in Aug vs. - 7.1% yoy in Jul).
Mexico was softer. Annual growth moderated to \(+0.8\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(+3.1\%\) yoy in Jun), while unemployment remained broadly stable at \(2.8\%\) . Headline inflation softened

to \(3.5\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(4.3\%\) yoy in Jun), while food inflation ticked up to \(5.1\%\) yoy (+20bp sequentially). Remittances in US\$ declined by - 16.2% yoy in Jun, and are no longer supported by MXN depreciation (- 11.6% yoy decline in LC). ANTAD SSS growth slowed to \(+2.4\%\) yoy in Jul (from \(+4.7\%\) yoy in Jun).

Argentina was mixed, as headline inflation eased to \(38\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(41\%\) yoy in Jun), but consumption confidence deteriorated by - 3.7% yoy in Dec (from \(+18\%\) yoy in Jul). Chile was positive. Real retail sales growth accelerated to \(+5.9\%\) yoy in Jun (vs. \(+2\%\) yoy in May), and consumer confidence grew at stronger \(+25.7\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(+8.0\%\) yoy in Jun), while headline inflation accelerated slightly to \(4.3\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(4.1\%\) yoy in Jun). Colombia was mostly positive. Avg real wages growth remains strong, at \(+3.5\%\) yoy in Jun (vs. \(+4.0\%\) yoy in May), while unemployment dropped by 40bp mom to \(8.6\%\) in the same month. Peru was mostly positive, as unemployment improved to \(6.1\%\) in Jul (vs. \(6.4\%\) in Jun), and headline inflation remained stable at \(1.7\%\) yoy, although we note that consumer confidence decelerated to \(+2.8\%\) yoy in Jul (from \(+11.2\%\) yoy in Jun).

Exhibit 3: Real core retail sales growth slowed to \(+0.3\%\) yoy in June (from \(+1.7\%\) yoy in May). Purchasing power improved in June, as the gap between avg. nominal wage and food inflation widened to \(+220bp\) (vs. \(+120bp\) in May).

Exhibit 4: In June, real food real retail sales were flat yoy (from \(+0.8\%\) yoy in May), while durables sales decreased by \(- 0.4\%\) yoy (from \(+7.1\%\) yoy in May). Apparel and HPC sales also decelerated to \(+6.4\% / + 1.9\%\) yoy respectively (from \(+6.7\% / + 5.5\%\) yoy the prior month). In the same period, plastic packaging production increased by \(+0.6\%\) yoy (vs. \(- 0.3\%\) yoy in May).

Exhibit 6: In July, headline inflation slowed to \(+3.5\%\) yoy (vs. \(+4.3\%\) yoy in June), despite the tick up in F&B inflation, which rose to \(+5.1\%\) yoy (vs. \(+4.9\%\) yoy in June). In the same period, average real wage growth slowed notably to \(+0.8\%\) yoy (vs. \(+3.1\%\) yoy the prior month). Worker remittances in US\$ weakened further, decreasing by \(-16.2\%\) in June (vs. \(-4.6\%\) yoy in May).

Exhibit 8: Real retail sales increased by \(+2.5\%\) yoy in June (vs. \(+2.7\%\) yoy in May), while wholesale sales declined by less, at \(- 8.9\%\) yoy (vs. \(- 9.1\%\) yoy in prior month). Self service and food retail sales growth slowed to \(+0.9\% / + 0.1\%\) yoy, respectively (from \(+2.6\% / + 6.8\%\) yoy in prior month). Meanwhile, apparel real retail sales growth flipped to negative levels, at \(- 4.3\%\) yoy (vs. \(+11.7\%\) yoy in May).

Exhibit 9: In July, bread prices ticked up slightly to \(+3.8\%\) yoy (vs. \(+3.7\%\) yoy the month before), alongside tortilla inflation, which accelerated slightly to \(+1.7\%\) yoy (vs. \(+1.6\%\) yoy in June). Corn flour prices growth remained stable at \(+3.2\%\) yoy, while milk prices increased by \(+8.3\%\) yoy (vs. \(+7.6\%\) yoy in June). Banknotes and coins available growth was steady at \(+8.6\%\) yoy in July (vs. \(+8.6\%\) yoy in June).
Source: Banco de Mexico, Bloomberg, INEGI, Haver Analytics, SNIIM

ASAI (Buy): For 2025E, our revenue and EBITDA forecast remain broadly unchanged, but our net income is up by \(+17\%\) after incorporating 2Q25 results (due to one- off tax credits). For 2026- 27E, our estimates remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at \(\mathbb{R}\S 13\)

SMFT (Buy): While our revenue and EBITDA estimates across 2025- 27E are broadly unchanged \((+1\%\) to \(+2\%\) ), our 2025E net income is up by \(+7\%\) , after incorporating 2Q25 beat (link). Given the slightly higher estimates and a lower WACC (after updating macro), our 12m fwd price target is up by \(+6\%\) to \(\mathbb{R}\S 34\)

VIVA (Buy): While our revenue estimates across 2025- 27E are broadly unchanged, our EBITDA is up by \(+4\%\) on average, as we incorporate a better- than- expected gross margin driven by the ramp- up of the factory, cost optimization, and a higher share of domestic Life products in the mix. Changes to our net income are mostly explained by changes to EBITDA. Our 12m fwd price target is up by \(+3\%\) to \(\mathbb{R}\S 34\)
Walmex (Buy): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at \(\mathbb{P}\S 67\)
SBFG (Neutral): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at \(\mathbb{R}\S 14\)

TBBB (Neutral): While we increase our 2025- 27E revenue estimates by \(+2\%\) on average after incorporating 2Q25 results, our EBITDA (ex. share- based compensation) estimate for 2025E is down by \(- 2\%\) on the back of higher- than- expected selling expenses. Our EBITDA (ex. SBC) estimates for 2026- 27E remain broadly unchanged. As we incorporate the non- cash expenses related to the stock options, RSUs and common shares granted in 2Q25 (link), our net income estimates are down significantly. That said, given that we already accounted for the dilution effect related to these grants in our share count, our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at US\$29.

Liverpool (Neutral): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. However, we reduce the number of Liverpool store openings in the longer term from 4 per year to nil given the relatively mature stage of the banner. As such, our 12m fwd price target declines by \(- 5\%\) to P\$119.

MGLU (Neutral): While our revenue and EBITDA estimates across 2025- 27E are broadly unchanged, our net income estimates are down by \(- 20\%\) on average, mainly explained by the impact of higher interest rate expectations on financial expenses, after updating macro. Given the lower estimates, our 12m fwd price target is down by \(- 14\%\) to R\$8.8.

NATU (Neutral): Our revenues are down by \(6\%\) on average across 2025- 28E as we incorporate 2Q25 results and lower topline trends for Hispanic Latam in the context of the Wave 2 roll- out in Mexico and Argentina. However, given the expectation of better profitability as the Wave 2 progresses, our EBITDA is down by a lower \(3\%\) on average. Our net income in 2025E is up after incorporating 2Q25 results. For 2026- 27E, changes to our net income are mainly explained by changes to EBITDA. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at R\$13, as the slightly lower estimates are offset by lower WACC (from \(15.5\%\) to \(15.2\%\) after updating macro in line with GS Economics).
PETZ (Neutral): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at R\$4.4

Cencosud (Sell): For 2025, our estimates remain broadly unchanged. For 2026- 27E, while our revenue projection remains broadly unchanged, our EBITDA is up by \(+3\%\) mainly due to better gross margin mix. Changes to our net income are mostly explained by changes to EBITDA. Our 12m fwd price is up by \(+2\%\) to CLP 1,880
BHIA (Sell): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at R\$3.2.

Falabella (Sell): While our revenue and EBITDA estimates across 2025- 27E are broadly unchanged, our 2025E net income is up by \(+25\%\) , after incorporating 2Q25 results (link). Our 12m fwd price target is up by \(+2\%\) to CLP3,460, after rolling our target one period fwd.
Soriana (Sell): Our estimates across 2025- 27E remain broadly unchanged. Our 12m fwd price target remains unchanged at

CompanyRatingMethodologyKey RisksASAIBuyEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 13.9%) and a forward P/E multiple of 11.3X.Key downside risks include: (i) slower-than-expected SSS growth driving downside to EBITDA and EPS expectations; (ii) higher rates impacting EPS expectations; (iii) delays or cost overruns in the execution of future store openings plans; (iv) lower average productivity or returns in incremental new locations; (v) weaker consumer backdrop.SMFTBuyEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 14.4%) and a forward P/E multiple of 17.0X.Key downside risks include: (i) potential macro headwinds, ii) increased competitive activity, iii) rising density resulting in cannibalization, iv) execution of future expansion, and v) overhang from potential stake reduction of relevant shareholders weighing on share price.VIVABuyEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 14.2%) and a forward P/E multiple of 10.8X.Key downside risks include: (i) Execution risks related to future store expansion (national and international); (ii) corporate governance risks related to strategy shifts in the context of management changes; (iii) potentially higher competition coming from niche brands, especially in the silver space; (iv) slowdown in the consumption environment in the context of high interest rates; and (iv) any potential disruptions in the factory driving operating deleverage and potentially a higher level of imports.WalmexBuyEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 11.2) and a forward P/E multiple of 19.4X.Key downside risks include: (i) slower SSS growth; (ii) renewed pricing and mix pressures; (iii) increased competition; (iv) execution of organic growth plan; (v) slower maturation of new stores/cannibalization; (vi) inflationary expense pressure.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Key downside risks include: (i) macro uncertainty in Mexico; (ii) execution risks as Liverpool rolls out new logistics and digital capabilities; (iii) competitive risks, especially from horizontal digital marketplaces/ecommerce platforms.NATUNeutral50/50 blend of a (i) FCFF DCF (WACC of 15.2%) and (ii) a 12-month forward target P/E multiple of 11.4X.Key upside risks include: (i) greater than expected resilience in end-consumer demand; (ii) favorable FX effects in the translation to its reporting currency, the BRL; (iii) potentially greater than expected resiliency of the direct sales channel through the macro cycle. Key downside risks include: (i) delays or new information in the announced separation from Avon Intl.; (ii) Wave 2 integration in LatAm ex-Brazil; (iii) risks related to macro landscape across LatAm, (iv) online competition and channel shift.MGLUNeutralEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 15.1%) and a forward EV/EBITDA multiple of 6.3X.Key upside risks include: (i) lower rates in Brazil; (ii) higher-than-expected sales growth and share gains at the B&amp;M operation; (iii) higher-than-expected GMV growth, especially at the higher margin 3P operation, and (iv) faster-than-expected margin ramp-up, driving earlier deleverage and higher earnings growth. Key downside risks include: (i) a lack of recovery in demand for its core durables offering, (ii) greater online competition, (iii) slower-than-expected ramp-up of new logistical solutions, and (iv) constraints to execution from a relatively leveraged balance sheet.PETZNeutralEqual-weighted blend of a FCFF DCF (WACC of 15.0%) and a forward P/E multiple of 19.5X.Key upside risks include: (i) better-than-expected ramp-up in new stores and therefore faster margin gains; (ii) self-help initiatives around cost cutting, refurbishments and private label. Key downside risks include: (i) macro scenario; (ii) potential competition from grocery retailers and horizontal marketplaces; (iii) execution of future expansion.

are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:
